# luminet ![ci-badge](https://img.shields.io/appveyor/build/bgmeulem/luminet?label=ci&style=flat-square) [![PyPI-badge](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/luminet?pypiBaseUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fpypi.org&style=flat-square&logo=pypi&logoColor=white&link=https%3A%2F%2Fpypi.org%2Fproject%2Fluminet%2F)](https://pypi.org/project/luminet) [![Documentation Status](https://readthedocs.org/projects/luminet/badge/?version=latest&style=flat-square)](https://luminet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest) ![coverage](https://img.shields.io/codecov/c/github/bgmeulem/Luminet?style=flat-square) ![stars-badge](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/bgmeulem/Luminet?style=flat-square) ![license](https://img.shields.io/github/license/bgmeulem/Luminet?style=flat-square) [![Pixi Badge](https://img.shields.io/endpoint?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/prefix-dev/pixi/main/assets/badge/v0.json&style=flat-square)](https://pixi.sh) Simulate and visualize Swarzschild black holes, based on the methods described in Luminet (1979). ![Example plot of a black hole](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bgmeulem/luminet/master/assets/bh_plot.png)
## ‚ö° Install `luminet` is available from PyPI:
Translation:
# luminet ![ci-badge](https://img.shields.io/appveyor/build/bgmeulem/luminet?label=ci&style=flat-square) [![PyPI-badge](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/luminet?pypiBaseUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fpypi.org&style=flat-square&logo=pypi&logoColor=white&link=https%3A%2F%2Fpypi.org%2Fproject%2Fluminet%2F)](https://pypi.org/project/luminet) [![Documentation Status](https://readthedocs.org/projects/luminet/badge/?version=latest&style=flat-square)](https://luminet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest) ![coverage](https://img.shields.io/codecov/c/github/bgmeulem/Luminet?style=flat-square) ![stars-badge](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/bgmeulem/Luminet?style=flat-square) ![license](https://img.shields.io/github/license/bgmeulem/Luminet?style=flat-square) [![Pixi Badge](https://img.shields.io/endpoint?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/prefix-dev/pixi/main/assets/badge/v0.json&style=flat-square)](https://pixi.sh) Simulez et visualisez des trous noirs de Schwarzschild, en vous basant sur les m√©thodes d√©crites dans Luminet (1979). ![Exemple de trac√© d‚Äôun trou noir](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bgmeulem/luminet/master/assets/bh_plot.png)
## ‚ö° Installation `luminet` est disponible sur PyPI :

RowTranslations.originContent: Simulate and visualize Swarzschild black holes, based on the methods described in Luminet (1979).
RowTranslations.translatedContent: Simulez et visualisez des trous noirs de Schwarzschild, en vous basant sur les m√©thodes d√©crites dans Luminet (1979).

All variables in this repo are in natural units: $G=c=1$

## üìñ [Documentation](https://luminet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html)

## üî© Utilisation

Toutes les variables de ce d√©p√¥t sont en unit√©s naturelles : $G=c=1$

RowTranslations.originContent: All variables in this repo are in natural units: $G=c=1$
RowTranslations.translatedContent: Toutes les variables de ce d√©p√¥t sont en unit√©s naturelles : $G=c=1$

Content:
```python
from luminet.black_hole import BlackHole
bh = BlackHole(
    mass=1,
    incl=1.5,           # inclination in radians
    acc=1,              # accretion rate
    outer_edge=40
)
```
Translation:
```python
from luminet.black_hole import BlackHole
bh = BlackHole(
    mass=1,
    incl=1.5,           # inclination in radians
    acc=1,              # accretion rate
    outer_edge=40
)
```

ax = bh.plot()          # Create image like above
```

```

Content: Note that sampling is biased towards the center of the black hole, since this is where most of the luminosity comes from. ## üìù Background Swarzschild black holes have an innermost stable orbit of $6M$, and a photon sphere at $3M$. This means that the accretion disk orbiting the black hole emits photons at radii $r>6M$. As long as the photon perigee in curved space remains larger than $3M$ (also called the photon sphere), the photon is not captured by the black hole and can in theory be seen from some observer frame $(b, \alpha)$. The spacetime curvature is most easily interpreted as a lensing effect between the black hole frame $(r, \alpha)$ and the observer frame $(b, \alpha)$. The former are 2D polar coordinates that span the accretion disk area, and the latter are 2D polar coordinates that span the "photographic plate" of the observer frame. Think of the latter as a literal CCD camera. The photon orbit perigee and the radius in observer frame $b$ are directly related: $$b^2 = \frac{P^3}{P-2M}$$ This makes many equations significantly more straightforward. You may notice this equation has a square on the left hand side, in contrast to Luminet (1979). The original manuscript has a handful of notation errors. I've contacted the author about this, to which he kindly responded: > "[...] √† l‚Äô√©poque je n'avais pas encore l‚Äôexp√©rience de relire tr√®s soigneusement les √©preuves. Mais mes calculs avaient heureusement √©t√© faits avec les bonnes formules, sinon le r√©sultat visuel n‚Äôaurait pas √©t√© correct!" > >"Back in the day, I did not have the habit of carefully double-checking my proofs. Luckily, I did calculate the results with the correct formulas, otherwise the image wouldn't be right!". Just so you know. I tried to be diligent about noting where this code differs from the paper. The relationship between the angles of both coordinate systems is trivial, but the relationship between the radii in the two reference frames is given by the monstruous Equation 13: $$\frac{1}{r} = - \frac{Q - P + 2M}{4MP} + \frac{Q-P+6M}{4MP}{sn}^2\left( \frac{\gamma}{2}\sqrt{\frac{Q}{P}} + F(\zeta_\infty, k) \right)$$ Here, $F$ is an incomplete Jacobian elliptic integral of the first kind, $k$ and $Q$ are a function of the perigee $P$, $\zeta$ are trigonometric functions of $P$, and $\gamma$ satisfies: $$\cos(\gamma) = \frac{\cos(\alpha)}{\sqrt{\cos^2\alpha + \cot^2\theta_0}}$$ In curved spacetime, there are usually multiple photon orbits that originate from the same coordinate and project to the ibserver frame (see e.g. gravitational lensing and Einstein crosses). Photon orbits that curve around the black hole and reach the observer frame are called "higher order" images, or "ghost" images. In this case, $\gamma$ satisfies: $$2n\pi - \gamma = 2\sqrt{\frac{Q}{P}} \left( 2K(k) - F(\zeta_\infty, k) - F(\zeta_r, k) \right)$$ These ghost photons are what you see on the lower half of the image above, as well as the barely visible halo of light that wraps thinly around the photon sphere. For inclinations that are less edge-on, this ghost image is less pronounced though. This repo uses `scipy.optimize.brentq` to solve these equations, and provides convenient API to the concepts presented in Luminet (1979). The `BlackHole` class is the most obvious one, but it's also educative to play around with e.g. the `Isoradial` class: lines in observer frame describing photons emitted from the same radius in the black hole frame. The `Isoredshift` class provides lines of equal redshift in the observer frame. ## üìï Bibliography [1] Luminet, J.-P., [‚ÄúImage of a spherical black hole with thin accretion disk.‚Äù](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1979A%26A....75..228L/abstract), Astronomy and Astrophysics, vol. 75, pp. 228‚Äì235, 1979. [2] J.-P. Luminet, [‚ÄúAn Illustrated History of Black Hole Imaging‚ÄØ: Personal Recollections (1972-2002).‚Äù](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.11196) arXiv, 2019. doi: 10.48550/ARXIV.1902.11196.
Translation: Notez que l‚Äô√©chantillonnage est biais√© vers le centre du trou noir, car c‚Äôest de l√† que provient la majeure partie de la luminosit√©. ## üìù Contexte Les trous noirs de Schwarzschild ont une orbite stable la plus proche √† $6M$, et une sph√®re de photons √† $3M$. Cela signifie que le disque d‚Äôaccr√©tion en orbite autour du trou noir √©met des photons √† des rayons $r>6M$. Tant que le p√©rig√©e du photon dans l‚Äôespace courbe reste sup√©rieur √† $3M$ (√©galement appel√© sph√®re de photons), le photon n‚Äôest pas captur√© par le trou noir et peut th√©oriquement √™tre vu d‚Äôun certain r√©f√©rentiel d‚Äôobservation $(b, \alpha)$. La courbure de l‚Äôespace-temps s‚Äôinterpr√®te le plus simplement comme un effet de lentille entre le r√©f√©rentiel du trou noir $(r, \alpha)$ et le r√©f√©rentiel de l‚Äôobservateur $(b, \alpha)$. Les premiers sont des coordonn√©es polaires 2D qui couvrent la surface du disque d‚Äôaccr√©tion, les seconds sont des coordonn√©es polaires 2D qui couvrent la ¬´ plaque photographique ¬ª du r√©f√©rentiel de l‚Äôobservateur. Pensez √† ce dernier comme √† un v√©ritable appareil CCD. Le p√©rig√©e de l‚Äôorbite du photon et le rayon dans le r√©f√©rentiel d‚Äôobservation $b$ sont directement reli√©s¬†: $$b^2 = \frac{P^3}{P-2M}$$ Cela simplifie consid√©rablement de nombreuses √©quations. Vous remarquerez que cette √©quation a un carr√© √† gauche, contrairement √† Luminet (1979). Le manuscrit original comporte quelques erreurs de notation. J‚Äôai contact√© l‚Äôauteur √† ce sujet, auquel il a aimablement r√©pondu¬†: > ¬´¬†[...] √† l‚Äô√©poque je n'avais pas encore l‚Äôexp√©rience de relire tr√®s soigneusement les √©preuves. Mais mes calculs avaient heureusement √©t√© faits avec les bonnes formules, sinon le r√©sultat visuel n‚Äôaurait pas √©t√© correct!¬†¬ª > >¬´¬†Back in the day, I did not have the habit of carefully double-checking my proofs. Luckily, I did calculate the results with the correct formulas, otherwise the image wouldn't be right!¬†¬ª. Pour information. J‚Äôai essay√© d‚Äô√™tre diligent pour noter o√π ce code diff√®re de l‚Äôarticle. La relation entre les angles des deux syst√®mes de coordonn√©es est triviale, mais la relation entre les rayons dans les deux r√©f√©rentiels est donn√©e par la monstrueuse √©quation 13¬†: $$\frac{1}{r} = - \frac{Q - P + 2M}{4MP} + \frac{Q-P+6M}{4MP}{sn}^2\left( \frac{\gamma}{2}\sqrt{\frac{Q}{P}} + F(\zeta_\infty, k) \right)$$ Ici, $F$ est une int√©grale elliptique de Jacobi incompl√®te du premier genre, $k$ et $Q$ sont des fonctions du p√©rig√©e $P$, $\zeta$ sont des fonctions trigonom√©triques de $P$, et $\gamma$ satisfait¬†: $$\cos(\gamma) = \frac{\cos(\alpha)}{\sqrt{\cos^2\alpha + \cot^2\theta_0}}$$ Dans l‚Äôespace-temps courbe, il y a g√©n√©ralement plusieurs orbites photoniques qui proviennent de la m√™me coordonn√©e et se projettent dans le r√©f√©rentiel de l‚Äôobservateur (voir par ex. le lentillage gravitationnel et les croix d‚ÄôEinstein). Les orbites de photons qui contournent le trou noir et atteignent l‚Äôobservateur sont appel√©es images ¬´¬†d‚Äôordre sup√©rieur¬†¬ª ou images ¬´¬†fant√¥mes¬†¬ª. Dans ce cas, $\gamma$ satisfait¬†: $$2n\pi - \gamma = 2\sqrt{\frac{Q}{P}} \left( 2K(k) - F(\zeta_\infty, k) - F(\zeta_r, k) \right)$$ Ces photons fant√¥mes sont ce que vous voyez dans la moiti√© inf√©rieure de l‚Äôimage ci-dessus, ainsi que l‚Äôaur√©ole de lumi√®re √† peine visible qui entoure finement la sph√®re de photons. Pour des inclinaisons moins rasantes, cette image fant√¥me est cependant moins marqu√©e. Ce d√©p√¥t utilise `scipy.optimize.brentq` pour r√©soudre ces √©quations, et fournit une API pratique pour les concepts pr√©sent√©s dans Luminet (1979). La classe `BlackHole` est la plus √©vidente, mais il est aussi instructif de manipuler par ex. la classe `Isoradial`¬†: lignes dans le r√©f√©rentiel de l‚Äôobservateur d√©crivant les photons √©mis depuis un m√™me rayon dans le r√©f√©rentiel du trou noir. La classe `Isoredshift` fournit les lignes d‚Äô√©gal d√©calage vers le rouge dans le r√©f√©rentiel de l‚Äôobservateur. ## üìï Bibliographie [1] Luminet, J.-P., [¬´¬†Image of a spherical black hole with thin accretion disk.¬†¬ª](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1979A%26A....75..228L/abstract), Astronomy and Astrophysics, vol. 75, pp. 228‚Äì235, 1979. [2] J.-P. Luminet, [¬´¬†An Illustrated History of Black Hole Imaging‚ÄØ: Personal Recollections (1972-2002).¬†¬ª](https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.11196) arXiv, 2019. doi: 10.48550/ARXIV.1902.11196.

The `BlackHole` class is the most obvious one, but it's also educative to play around with e.g. the `Isoradial` class: lines in observer frame describing photons emitted from the same radius in the black hole frame. The `Isoredshift` class provides lines of equal redshift in the observer frame.
